p.#text: Scene: Before the palace of Oedipus at Thebes. In front of the large central doors  there is an altar; a smaller altar stands also near each of the two side-doors: see verse 16. Suppliantsold men, youths, and young childrenare seated on the steps of the altars. They are dressed in white tunics and cloaks, their hair bound with white fillets. On the altars they have laid down olive-branches wreathed with fillets of wool. The PRIEST OF ZEUS, a venerable man, is alone standing, facing the central doors of the palace. These are now thrown open: followed by two attendants , who place themselves on either side of the doors, OEDIPUS enters, in the robes of a king: for a moment he gazes silently on the groups at the altars, and then speaks. See Appendix, Note 1, sect. 1.

div2.p: Oedipus asks why they are suppliants. The Priest of Zeus, speaking for the rest, prays him to save them, with the gods' help, from the blight and the plague. Oedipus answers that he has already sent Creon to consult Apollo at Delphi, and will do whatever the god shall bid.

Oed. asks: Does this supplication mean that  ? Or that    which I can grant?Others render  . This admits of two views. i Are ye  of suffering? Or have ye already  suffering? To this point the glosses . But this seems unmeaning. He  that the suffering has come, and he does not suppose that they are  to it cp. v. 58. ii Prof. Kennedy connects  i.e. are ye come in vague terror, or  that I would be willing to help you? This is ingenious and attractive. But (a) it appears hardly consonant with the kingly courtesy of this opening speech for Oedipus to assume that their belief in his good-will would reconcile them to their present miseries. (b) We seem to require some direct and express intimation of the king's willingness to help, such as the words  give only when referred to . (c) The rhythm seems to favour the question at  explained as , may be rejected, because 1 the sense is against itsee on i above: 2  in classical Greek = to be proof against, not to suffer: 3  are unknown to Attic, which has only the pres. and the imperf.  to be connected with   implies the apodosis of a conditional sentence. The other temple may be that of Athene  or of Athena  both mentioned by the schol., but not by Paus. Athena  too, had  at Thebes . The schol. mentions also  but her shrine was at the village of Alalcomenae near Haliartus . p.#text: I take these two verses with the whole context from v. 35, and not merely as a comment on the immediately preceding words  Oedipus has had practical experience  of great troubles; when the Sphinx came, his wisdom stood the trial. Men who have become thus  are apt to be   prudent in regard to the future. Past  enlighten the  which they offer on things still uncertain; and we observe that the issues of their counsels are not usually futile or dead, but effectual. Well may we believe, then, that he who saved us from the Sphinx can tell us how to escape from the plague. Note these points. 1 The words  and  serve to suggest the antithesis between past and future. 2 =  literally,  connected with resulting from . The phrase, issues of counsels, concisely expresses this. The objection which has been made to this version, that  is not  rests on a grammatical fallacy, viz., that, in  the genitive must be of the same kind as in  is not  yet in  it stands with a gen. of connection, just as  does here: a good fortune connected with this coming. i.e. may the god, who has summoned us to put away our pollution,  come among us as a healing presence.

The Chorus consists of Theban eldersmen of noble birth, the foremost in honour of the land (1223) who represent the  just summoned by Oedipus (144). Oedipus having now retired into the palace, and the suppliants having left the stage, the Chorus make their entrance  into the hitherto vacant  For the metres see the Analysis which follows the Introduction.  151-158. Is the god's message indeed a harbinger of health? Or has Apollo some further pain in store for us?  159-166. May Athene, Artemis, and Apollo succour us!  167-178. The fruits of the earth and the womb perish.  179-189. The unburied dead taint the air: wives and mothers are wailing at the altars.  190-202. May Ares, the god of death, be driven hence: may thy lightnings, O Zeus, destroy him.  203-215. May the Lycean Apollo, and Artemis, and Dionysus fight for us against the evil god.

of a god's utterance or oracle 1440, a poet. equivalent for :  cp. 310  , because Zeus speaks by the mouth of his son;  , merely a general propitiatory epitnet: the Chorus have not yet heard whether the response is comforting or not. Oedipus has just learned from Creon that Laius was believed to have been murdered by robbers on his way to Delphi, but that, owing to the troubles caused by the Sphinx, no effective search had been made at the time 114-131. He has at once resolved to take up the matterboth because Apollo enjoins it, and as a duty to the Theban throne 255. But the murder occurred before he had come to Thebes. He must therefore appeal for some clue  su/mbolon

If the culprit is denounced by another person, he will be liable to the extreme penalty. If he denounces himself, he will merely be banished. This was a sentence of excommunication 1 from the life of the family and the clan, 2 from the worship common to all Hellenes, who, as opposed to  are   The mere presence of the guilty could render sacrifice inauspicious:

p.#text: common things   =  consisting  kindred children would have been generated: =  a brood, common to Laius and Oedipus, of children akin to each other as having the same mother, Iocasta would have issued: children born of one mother would have made ties between him and me. For  doubled cp. 139, 339.  = .  The language of this passage is carefully framed so as to bear a second meaning, of which the speaker is unconscious, but which the spectators can feel: Iocasta has actually borne children to her own son Oedipus: thus in  the obvious sense of  , has behind it a second sense, in which it hints at a brood who are : see below 1403 f. This subtle emphasisso ghastly,  of the iteration in  must not be obliterated by amending  into  Nauck or  Blaydes. Similarly, , is susceptible of the senseif his son Oed. himself had not been ill-fated.  his hope of issue was disappointed is here a bold phrase for :  for Oed. is not  supposed to know the story of the exposed babe see 717 f.. p.#text: :  to seer-craft: for dat., cp.

First  Teiresias has just denounced Oedipus. Why do not the Chorus at once express their horror? This ode is the first since v. 215, and therefore, in accordance with the conception of the Chorus as personified reflection, it must comment on all that has been most stirring in the interval. Hence it has two leading themes: 1 Who can be the murderer?: 1st strophe and antistrophe, referring to vv. 216-315. 2 I will not believe that it is Oedipus: n)d strophe and antistrophe, referring to vv. 316-462.  463-472. Who is the murderer at whom the Delphic oracle hints? He should fly: Apollo and the Fates are upon him.  473-482. The word has gone forth to search for him. Doubtless he is hiding in waste places, but he cannot flee his doom.  483-497. Teiresias troubles me with his charge against Oedipus: but I know nothing that confirms it.  498-512. Only gods are infallible; a mortal, though a seer, may be wrong. Oedipus has given proof of worth. Without proof, I will not believe him guilty.

p.#text: the message flashed forth like a beacon from that snow-crowned range which the Thebans see to the west. I have elsewhere noted some features of the view from the Dryoscephalae pass over Mount Cithaeron:At a turn of the road the whole plain of Boeotia bursts upon the sight, stretched out far below us. There to the north-west soars up Helicon, and beyond it, Parnassus; and  Just opposite, nearly due north, is Thebes, on a low eminence with a range of hills behind it, and the waters of Lake Copais to the north-west, gleaming in the afternoon sun. , p. 75.

p.title: Antigone
p.#text: with  649-697. Oedipus upbraids Creon with having suborned Teiresias. The quarrel is allayed by Iocasta. As she and Oedipus converse, he is led to fear that he may unwittingly have slain Laius. It is resolved to send for the surviving eye-witness of the deed. Oedipus had directly charged Creon with plotting to usurp the throne 385. Creon's defence serves to bring out the character of Oedipus by a new contrast. Creon is a man of somewhat rigid nature, and essentially matter-of-fact. In his reasonable indignation, he bases his argument on a calculation of interest 583, insisting on the substance in contrast with the show of power, as in the  his vindication of the written law ignores the unwritten. His blunt anger at a positive wrong is softened by no power of imagining the mental condition in which it was done. He cannot allow for the tumult which the seer's terrible charge excited in the mind of Oedipus, any more than for the conflict of duties in the mind of Antigone.

p.#text: all men wish me joy: lit. I rejoice with the consent of all men: all are content that I should rejoice. Cp.  all deem you undeserving of misfortune:  The phrase has been suggested by  but refers to the meaning rather than to the form of the greeting: i.e.  is not to be regarded as if it meant literally, I have the word  said to me by all. This is one of the boldly subtle phrases in which the art of Soph. recalls that of Vergil. Others understand: 1 I rejoice in all, instead of suspecting some, as the  does, who  : 2 I rejoice in relation to all i.e. am on good terms with all: 3 I rejoice in the sight of all: i.e. enjoy a happiness which is the greater because men see it: 4 I rejoice in all things. This last is impossible. Of the others, 1 is best, but not in accord with the supposed position of Oedipus

Creon has been arguing that  has no motive for treason. He now states a general maxim, No mind would ever turn to treason, while it was sound. As a logical inference, this holds good only of those who are in Creon's fortunate case. If, on the other hand,  means alive to its own  good, and not merely to such self-interest as that of which Creon has spoken, then the statement has no strict connection with what precedes: it becomes a new argument of a different order, which might be illustrated from Plato's  It would be forcing the words to render: A base mind could not approve itself wise, i.e. such treason as you ascribe to me would be silly.

p.#text: . 1 Verse 624,  which the MSS. give to Creon, belongs to Oedipus: and for  we should I think read . The argument that the stichomuthia should not be broken shows inattention to the practice of Soph. He not seldom breaks a stichomuthia, when a weighty utterance as here, the king's threat claims the emphasis of two verses. See e.g. 356-369, broken by 366 f. the seer's denunciation: , broken by 45 f. Antigone's resolve: , broken by 583 f. where Theseus marks the singularity in the proposal of Oed.. 2 Verse 625  which the MSS. give to Oedipus, belongs to Creon. 3 Between 625 and 626 a verse spoken by Oedipus has dropped out, to such effect as  The fact of the next verse, our 626, also beginning with  may have led to the loss by causing the copyist's eye to wander. p.#text: ethic dat.:  =  : . partitive gen. The  have prescience 498; but they impart it to no , not even to such ministers as the Delphian priests. Iocasta reveres the gods 647: it is to them, and first to Apollo, that she turns in trouble 911. But the shock which had befallen her own life, when at the bidding of Delphi her first-born was sacrificed without saving her husband Laiushas left a deep and bitter conviction that no mortal, be he priest or seer, shares the divine foreknowledge. In the Greek view the  might be 1 first, the god himself, speaking through a divinely frenzied being in whom the human reason was temporarily superseded hence the popular derivation of  from : : this was much the same as the Egyptian belief,  2 Secondly, the  might be a man who reads signs from birds, fire, etc., by rule of mystic science: it was against this  that scepticism most readily turned:  Iocasta means:  I will not say that the message came through the lips of a truly god-possessed interpreter; but at any rate it came from the priests; it was an effort of human . So in 946, 953  are oracles which  to come from the gods. Others render:  Nothing in mortal affairs  the mantic art: i.e. is affected by it, comes within its ken. p.title: Modern Greece
p.#text: In going from Thebes to Delphi, the traveller passes by these  Branching Roads, still known as the  but better as the : from Daulia it is a leisurely ride of about an hour and a half along the side of Parnassus. The following is from my notes taken on the spot:  A bare isolated hillock of grey stone stands at the point where our path from Daulia meets the road to Delphi, and a third road that stretches to the south. There, in front, we are looking up the road down which Oedipus came [from Delphi]; we are moving in the steps of the man whom he met and slew; the road runs up a wild and frowning pass between Parnassus on the right hand and on the left the spurs of the Helicon range, which here approach it. Away to the south a wild and lonely valley opens, running up among the waste places of Helicon, a vista of naked cliffs or slopes clothed with scanty herbage, a scene of inexpressible grandeur and desolation  p. 79. At this  Pausanias saw : the legend was that Damasistratus king of Thebes had found the bodies and buried them 10. 5 sect. 4. The spot has a modern monument which appeals with scarcely less force to the imagination of a visitor, the tomb of a redoubtable brigand who was killed in the neighbourhood many years ago.

p.#text: marks keen interest:

The poet has neglected clearness on a minor point. The  sole survivor of the four attendantshad fled back to Thebes with the news that Laius had been slain by robbers 118-123. This news came before the trouble with the Sphinx began: 126-131. And the play supposes an interval of at least several days between the death of Laius and the election of Oedipus: see on 736. Hence  cannot mean that the  on reaching Thebes, found Oedipus already reigning. Nor can we suggest that he may have fled from the scene of the slaughter before he was  that Laius had been killed: that is excluded by 123 and 737. Therefore we must understand: when he had come thence, and [] found that  was Laius dead,  you were his successor. For the parataxis  see on 673. I incline to suspect, however, that Sophocles was  thinking of the man as coming back to find Oedipus already on the throne, and had overlooked the inconsistency. The conjecture  for  Wolff would remove the difficulty, but seems very improbable.

p.title: Introd.
p.#text: The hand which added this verse in the margin of L seems to be  as early as the beginning of the fourteenth century Mr E. M. Thompson,  to Facsimile of Laur. MS.. The verse is in A 1t(h cent. and all our other MSS. To eject the verse, as Dindorf and Nauck have done, is utterly unwarrantable. It has a fine dramatic force. Oedipus is now at the critical point: he will hide nothing of the truth from her who is nearest to him. It is part of his character that his earnest desire to know the  never flinches: cp. 1170.

The  is, I think, identical with the , and distinct from the . I understand the scene thus. Oedipus was coming down the steep narrow road when he met the  to be known for such by his stave,  walking in front of the carriage .The herald rudely bade him stand aside; and Laius, from the carriage, gave a like command. With the imperfect , were for driving,  need not mean more than a threat or gesture. The driver ,who was walking at his horses  heads up the hill, then did his lord's bidding by actually jostling the wayfarer . Oedipus, who had forborne to strike the sacred herald, now struck the ; in another moment, while passing the carriage, he was himself struck on the head by Laius. He dashed Laius from the carriage; the herald, turning back, came to the rescue; and Oedipus slew Laius, herald, driver, and one of two servants who had been walking by or behind the carriage; the other servant unperceived by Oedipus escaped to Thebes with the news.

Wunder and others think this verse spurious. But it is, in fact, of essential moment to the development of the plot. Oedipus fears that he has slain Laius, but does not yet dream that Laius was his father. This verse accentuates the point at which his belief now stands, and so prepares us for the next stage of discovery. The peculiarity of the idiom is that the second part of the compound is equivalent to a  epithet for the noun: i. e. , with solitary girdle,  signifies,  alone, and girt up.   not,  with a hundred feet each,  but, countless, and dancing:  not, thickly-feathered, but, many and winged:  not, separately-journeying sisters, but, two sisters, journeying:  not, diversely-reigning kings, but, two reigning kings:  not, a youth with one child, but, a youth, his only child:  not, goddesses with contrasted names, but, several goddesses, each of whom is invoked. p.#text: Second  The second  512-862 has been marked by the overbearing harshness of Oedipus towards Creon; by the rise of a dreadful suspicion that Oedipus is  blood-guilty for Laius; and by the avowed contempt of Iocasta, not, indeed, for Apollo himself, but for the  of his ministers. These traits furnish the two interwoven themes of the second stasimon: 1 the prayer for  in word as in deed: 2 the deprecation of that  which goes before a fall; whether it be the insolence of the  or such intellectual arrogance as Iocasta's speech bewrays  v. 884. The tone of warning reproof towards Oedipus, while only allusive, is yet in contrast with the firm though anxious sympathy of the former ode, and serves to attune the feeling of the spectators for the approach of the catastrophe.  863-872. May I ever be pure in word and deed, loyal to the unwritten and eternal laws.  873-882. A tyrant's selfish insolence hurls him to ruin. But may the gods prosper all emulous effort for the good of the State.  883-896. Irreverence in word or deed shall not escape: the wrath of the gods shall find it out.  897-910. Surely the oracles concerning Laius will yet be justified: O Zeus, suffer not Apollo's worship to fail.

A messenger from Corinth, bringing the news that Polybus is dead, discloses that Oedipus was not that king's son, but a Theban foundling, whom the messenger had received from a servant of Laius. Iocasta, failing to arrest the inquiries of Oedipus, rushes from the scene with a cry.

Iocasta comes forth, bearing a branch  wreathed with festoons of wool  which, as a suppliant, she is about to lay on the altar of the household god, Apollo  in front of the palace. The state of Oedipus frightens her. His mind has been growing more and more excited. It is not that she herself has much fear for the future. What alarms her is to see  the pilot of the ship  923 thus unnerved. Though she can believe no longer in   she has never ceased to revere the  708; and to them she turns for help in her need.

p.title: Iliad
p.#text: Whatever may have been his human parentage, Oed. is the  son of Fortune  said in a very different tone from  in : Fortune brings forth the months with their varying events; these months, then, are his brothers, who ere now have known him depressed as well as exalted. He has faith in this Mother, and will not shrink from the path on which she seems to beckon him; he will not be false to his sonship. We might recall Schiller's epigram on the Wolfians; whatever may be the human paternity of the ,

p.title: Ajax
p.#text: This short ode holds the place of the third  But it has the character of a  dance-song  or  a melody of livelier movement, expressing joyous excitement. The process of discovery now approaches its final phase. The substitution of a hyporcheme for a regular stasimon has here a twofold dramatic convenience. It shortens the interval of suspense; and it prepares a more forcible contrast. For the sake of thus heightening the contrast, Soph. has made a slight sacrifice of probability. The sudden exit of Iocasta has just affected the Chorus with a dark presentiment of evil 1075. We are now required to suppose that the spirited words of Oedipus 1076-1085 have completely effaced this impression, leaving only delight in the prospect that he will prove to be a native of the land. A hyporcheme is substituted for a stasimon with precisely similar effect in the , where the short and joyous invocation of Pan immediately precedes the catastrophe 693-717. The stasimon in  may also be compared, in so far as its glad anticipations usher in the beginning of the end.  1086-1097. Our joyous songs will soon be celebrating Cithaeron as native to Oedipus.  1098-1109. Is he a son of some god, of Pan or Apollo, of Hermes or Dionysus?

p.#text: the full-moon of to-morrow,  acc. of  there is no adj.  as  acc. of   At Athens the great Dionysia were immediately followed by the  a festival held at full-moon in the middle of the month Elaphebolion at the beginning of April: cp. A. Mommsen  p. 389, and C. F. Hermann  2.59. Wolff remarks that, if this play was produced on the last day of the Dionysia, the poet would have known that arrangement long beforehand, and may have intended an allusion to the  which his Athenian hearers would quickly seize. This would explain why precisely  to-morrow's fullmoon  is named. Nauck reads as =  the coming  full-moon: Wecklein, dat. of  the vernal full-moon  that, namely, in Elaphebolion.

The herdsman of Laius is confronted with the messenger from Corinth. It is discovered that Oedipus is the son of Laius.

The  who alone escaped from the slaughter of Laius and his following, had at his own request been sent away from Thebes to do the work of a herdsman 761. Is he identical with that herdsman of Laius 1040 who had given up the infant Oedipus to the Corinthian shepherd? He is now seen approaching. With his coming, the two threads of discovery are brought together.

March to September. In March the herd of Polybus drove his flock up to Cithaeron from Corinth, and met the herd of Laius, who had brought up his flock from the plain of Thebes. For six months they used to consort in the upland glens of Cithaeron; then, in September, when Arcturus began to be visible a little before dawn, they parted, taking their flocks for the winter into homesteads near Corinth and Thebes.

It may be rendered   the winter, since it involves the notion of the time  which the flock was to remain in the  It is, however, one of those temporal accusatives which are almost adverbial, the idea of duration being merged in that of season, so that they can even be used concurrently with a temporal genitive:  2.95  2.2  at the due season. 7.151  Cp. above, 1090  The tendency to such a use of the accus. may have been an old trait of the popular language cp. , . p.#text: The MSS. give [sic; in one MS. . I conjecture : I lament as one who pours from his lips a dirge : i.e., Oedipus is to me as one who is dead. Cp.  over the tomb they poured forth a resounding dirge.  My emendation has been adopted by Prof. Kennedy ed. 1885. Every attempt to explain the vulgate is unavailing. 1  is supposed to be like  in measure most abundant.  Now  could mean only ,  : Soph. fr. 225  strains which Thamyras weaves :  why have I, Andromeda, been dowered with sorrows ?  honoured . Here,  is utterly unsuitable; and the added  makes the phrase stranger still. 2 The MSS. have . Both  and  occur: but the latter should, with Dindorf, be written  : 783 : : 965  The participle, however, is unendurably weak after , and leaves  weaker still. 3  can mean only  the plur. as  kissing her lips: : it could not mean  loudly.  4 Elmsley, doubtless feeling this, took  as gen. of a supposed, but most questionable,  loud, formed from  Erfurdt conjectured , from lips wild as a bacchant's. But a Greek poet would not have brought Iacchos and Thanatos so close together;  5  gives exactly the right force; for them, Oed. is as the dead.  is  in the four places of Eur. where it occurs , , , , in , and in the one place of , which is just to our point: the Chorus of Danaides say,  lamenting sorrows meet for funeral wails i.e. the sorrows of those who are as dead, while yet living, I chant mine own dirge.  fits , since  was not commonly used absolutely for to utter as by Pindar, l. c. above. 6 The corruption may have thus arisen in a cursive MS.:  being written  the last five letters of  would first generate  as in one MS., or, with the second stroke of the : the attempt to find an intelligible word in the immediately preceding group of letters would then quickly produce the familiar  in one MS.  The nonelision of the final  in the MSS. favours this view. As to metre, with  in 1209, a tribrach  answers to a dactyl  my  whether we keep the traditional text, or adopt my conjecture, or that of Wecklein or of Burges; though Wecklein, by a strange oversight, has noticed this objection as if it were peculiar to my conjecture. We are to suppose that, when she rushed from the scene in her passionate despair 1072, Iocasta passed through the central door of the palace  into the  a short passage or hall, opening on the court  surrounded by a colonnade  Across this court she hurried to the  or bedroom of the master and mistress of the house, and shut herself into it. Presently Oedipus burst into the court with that cry of which we heard the first accents 1182 as he fled from the scene ,1252. The messenger and others who were in the court watch him in terror as he raves for a sword and asks for Iocasta. Then the thought strikes him that she is in the  He bursts into it 1261. They follow. There they find Iocasta dead, and see Oedipus blind himself.

p.#text: Cp. , Eng. tr. 92:  It seems to me best on all grounds to suppose that shortly before the rise of the Greek Epic the [syllabic] augment became occasionally exposed to the same tendency towards wearing away  which the  of  and the  of  could not always withstand; that there were, in short, pairs of forms then in use, one with the augment and one withoutThe omission of the syllabic augment in Homer was purely a matter of choicePost-Homeric poetry adopts the power of dispensing with the syllabic augment as an inheritance from its predecessor, and makes the greater use of it in proportion as it is removed from the language of ordinary life. Hence it is that, as is shown by the careful investigations made by Renner  1.2.18 ff., the omission of the syllabic augment is extremely rare in iambic, and far more common in elegiac and lyric verse. Hence, as is shown  1.2.259 by Gerth, in the dialogue of tragedy the range of this license is very limited indeed, while the majority of instances of it occur in the slightly Epic style of the messengers speeches, or still more commonly in lyric passages.  The tragic  here borrow from a practice more marked in epic  than in epic . In Homer, where augmented and unaugmented forms are on the whole about equally numerous, the proportion of augmented to unaugmented is in the speeches about 10 to 3, in the narrative about 5 to 7: see Monro,  sect. 69.

A  see p. 9. The Chorus begin with anapaests 1297 -1306. The first words uttered by Oedipus are in the same measure 1307 -1311. Then, after a single iambic trimeter spoken by the Chorus 1312, 1  1313-1320 = 2  1321-1328; 3  1329 -1348 = 4  1349-1368. Oedipus here speaks in dochmiac measures blended with iambic; the Chorus, in iambic trimeters or dimeters only. The effect of his passionate despair is thus heightened by metrical contrast with a more level and subdued strain of sorrow. Compare , where the  has in this sense a like character. Some regard the  as beginning only at 1313; less correctly, I think. Its essence is the antiphonal lament rather than the antistrophic framework.

who is the deity that hath sprung upon thy hapless life with a leap greater than the longest leap? i.e. has given thee sorrow which almost exceeds the imaginable limit of human suffering?  For  see on 465  The idea of a malignant god leaping  on his victim is frequent in Greek tragedy: see on 263. But here , as in 311  combines the notion of swooping from above with that of leaping  as with Pindar   denote  poetical efforts. We should then conceive the  the ill-fated life, as an attacked region,  which the malign god springs. Here we see a tendency which may sometimes be observed in the imagery lyric especially of Sophocles: the  is slightly crossed and blurred by the interposing notion of the : as here he was thinking,  what suffering ? See on  866. With Aeschylus, on the other hand, the obscurity of imagery seldom or never arises from indistinctness of outline, but more often from an opposite cause, the vividly objective conception of abstract notions.

p.#text: with  emphasises . Oedipus had been the all-admired 8, the  saviour of the land  48. But now the Theban elders wish that they had never so much as heard his name or looked upon his face. That bitter cry is drawn from them by the very strength of their sympathy: for his ruin was the result of his coming to Thebes. The objections to the reading of the MSS., , are these: 1  has the 1st aor. pass.,  we should have been recognised : but  occurs nowhere else in tragedy; and in Attic its regular sense was  to read, or in the 1st aor. act.,  to persuade. I have not found a single example of  as =   to recognise  in Thuc., Plato, Xen., or the Orators. 2 But the 2nd aor. has that sense in Homer, in  and in : may not an Attic poet have followed them? Granted. The sense required here, however, after , is to , not to : the latter would be pointless. 3 The ellipse of  with the aor.  would be strangely harsh. p.#text: The  of the MSS. is corrupt. It would require an improbable alteration in the strophe see on 1330; and it yields no good sense. The Scholiasts hesitated between rendering it 1  feeding on my flesh ! or 2  in the pastures. Reading , we have a dochmiac dimeter, agreeing with 1330: see Metrical Analysis. But the use of the word is extraordinary. It must mean  in the pasturessaid of the babe whom the shepherd had been ordered to expose on Cithaeron. Now elsewhere  always means  said e.g. of pastoral tribes, or of animals:  tracking horse : fr. 87 : of waters  over the land which they irrigate,  The idea of wandering movement is inseparable from the word. To apply it to a babe whose feet were pinned together would have been indeed a bold use. Prof. Campbell, retaining  takes  as acc. plur.:  that loosed the cruel clog upon my feet, . But could , roaming,  be said of the maimed child merely in the sense of  by its parents? The nomin. , referring to the roving shepherd  1029 would be intelligible; but the quadruple  is against it. Now cp.  Xerxes alone and forlorn.  Simply transposing  and  I conjecture , a word appropriate to the complaint that the babe, sent to the lonely mountain, had not been left to perish in its solitude. The fact that the Corinthian shepherd received the child from the Theban is no objection: the child was  desolate and forlorn. , which suits the dochmiac as well as  is more forcible here. There is a further argument for it. The MSS. give  in 1349, but the strophe 1329 shows that  must be omitted, since  = , the first syllable of  being short, as in 1205, , 1124. Now  i.e.  ,  the fetter, would be too harsh: we could only do as Schneidewin did, and refer  back to : but though  734 admits of such treatment, the case is dissimilar here. On the other hand ,  the fetter, is correct. Thus the metrical impossibility of  confirms . The epithet  cruel,  is applied to  as it is to  in .

p.title: Oedipus
p.#text: His memory recalls the scene as if he were again approaching it on his way from Delphi. First, he descries three roads converging in a deep glen or ravine :then, descending, he comes to a coppice at a point where his own road narrows just before its junction with the two others .See on 733. The genuineness of v. 1399 has been groundlessly questioned, on the score of supposed tautology. The language may be compared with that of the verses from the  of Aeschylus fr. 167, quoted in the Introduction.
thus divided from , is more than :  the same blood which flows in my own veinsthe blood of my father.

For , which has a tone of bitterness here, see on 124, 969. The  of the MSS. must be explained in one of two ways: 1 as if the construction was irregularly changed by : but the immediate succession of  to  makes this intolerably harsh: or 2 as if  were exclamatory substitutes for  or the like: which seems inadmissible.

By the change of one letter, we restore sense to the passage. The  of the MSS. is unintelligible. Oedipus was the  of Laius and Iocasta. When Iocasta weds Oedipus, the marriage cannot be said : for it is absurd to suppose that  could be identified with . But the marriage can be rightly said  to yield seed  Oedipus whom that womb had borne.

p.#text: The marriage of Iocasta with Oedipus constituted Oedipus at once  of his children, while he was also  of his wife,the closest relation in  becoming also the . The marriage made Iocasta the  aye, and the child-bearing  ,of him to whom she was also  .Thus, through the birth of children from such a marriage, complex horrors of relationship arose  is in apposition with , a blood-kinship standing for  a blood-kinsman. It expresses that the monstrous union confounded the closest tie of  with the closest tie of . The phrase  like  would in Tragedy more often mean  murder of a kinsman. But it can, of course, mean also  kindred blood in another sense; and here the context leaves no ambiguity. Cp.  n.

the blind man asks that they will lead him away from Thebes, and  him from the sight of men in some lonely spotas amid the wilds of Cithaeron 1451. We must not transpose  and , as is done in Schneidewin's ed. as revised by Nauck, after Burges.
cp. Appendix, note on v. 478. Cp.  n. -  with fut. indic., as , , .

No one can share the burden of his ills. Other men need not fear to be polluted by contact with him, as with one guilty of blood. His unwitting crimes and his awful sufferingsalike the work of Apolloplace him apart. In illustration of the fear which he seeks to allay, compare the plea of Orestes that, since he has been duly purified from bloodshed, contact with him has ceased to be dangerous  Contrast , where Oed. will not allow his benefactor Theseus to touch him. , he feels that he is still formally  and that gratitude forbids him to impart a possible taint. , he thinks only of his unique doom and his incommunicable anguish.

p.#text: Nauck gives these verses to Oedipus, making them follow 1415. He regards   as inconsistent with the profession which Creon has just made. Rather may we consider them as showing a kinsman's anxious and delicate concern for the honour of Oedipus and of the house 1430. Creon, deeply moved, deprecates the prolonged indulgence of a painful curiosity cp. 1304. It is again Creon who says  1515 when Oedipus would fain linger. Clearly, then, these verses are rightly placed in the MSS.

p.#text: The words  form the decisive argument for the  of the MSS. against Toup's specious emendation, . His parents in  appointed Cithaeron to be his grave. Now they are dead; but, though he can no longer die by their , he wishes to die  ; i.e. by selfexposure in the same wilds to which they had consigned him cp. 719  The thought of the  bringing death upon the living is one which Sophocles has also in   Heracles speaking of Nessus : . The reading , on the other hand, yields nothing but a weak verbal antithesis with . Had his parents meant him to  in lonely misery on Cithaeron, there would be some point in calling it his  living grave.  But they meant him to die there forthwith cp. 1174;  then, would mean nothing more than that the grave was chosen before the babe was dead.

p.#text: = I am confident that nothing can destroy me   is admissible since  here =  and  represents a negative conception of the mind. So with partic.  would be more usual; the difference being that this would be the oblique form of  The ordinary usage is 1  with infin. (= with indic. after verbs of saying or thinking,  etc; 2  with infin. after verbs of feeling confident, promising, etc., as  But a few exceptions occur both ways, when a verb of either class is virtually equivalent to a verb of the other: e.g. (1) = but   : (2)    but    Cp. Whitelaw in  1886 p. 34, and Gildersleeve in  1.49. Whitelaw here takes  as =  and reads  not :  my parents wished to kill me; but nothing could have killed me; I was reserved for  dread evil.  Surely, however, it is better to connect the verses with the wish for death which he has just uttered. The poet of Colonus gives Oedipus a presentiment that his end is not to be as that of other men.

p.#text: The poet is thinking of his own Athens, though the language is general.  comprises all occasions on which Attic women could appear in public, as at the delivery of  :  suggests such festivals as the Thesmophoria, the Panathenaea, or the Dionysia when women were present in the theatre, at least at tragedy. To feel the force of this passage, we must remember how closely the Greek festivals were bound up with the life of the . Kinsfolk took part in them together: and at such moments a domestic disgrace, such as that which the sisters inherited, would be most keenly felt. In Athenian law-courts the fact of association at festivals could be cited in evidence of family intimacy:  public spectacle   in the theatre  It was the Attic custom for a bridegroom  to provide a banquet at the next Thesmophoria for the women of his deme , and also  to provide a banquet for his clansmen when his bride was introduced into his  .

The disgraces are  to the sons and daughters as involving their ruin in life: but could not be called  to the  in the remote figurative sense of . Nor would there be any fitness in the conjuction of harm  to the living. Oedipus here thinks of the living, and of the future, alone. cp. 1357,  has come to be most hateful. Creon's reply, , means:  if the gods  desire thy banishment, thou wilt soon have thy wishwhen the oracle at Delphi is consulted 1443. According to the story which Soph. follows, Oedipus was at first detained at Thebes against his own wish. But when some time had elapsed, and that wish had given place to a calmer mood, the Thebans, in their turn, demanded his expulsion; and Creon then yielded .

In  Creon is represented as opposing a distinct refusal to this prayer of Oedipus. His words here could mean:  No, I do not promise, for I am not wont to speak vain words when I lack knowledge  as in 569: i.e., I cannot tell how Apollo may decide. But I now think that, on the whole, it suits the context better to take them as expressing consent  = what I do not mean to do. p.#text: See critical note. These verses are spoken by the Chorus, as Creon turns with Oedipus to enter the house. The calm close which the tragedy requires would be wanting if they were spoken by the chief sufferer himself. Of extant Greek tragedies, the  and the  are the only ones which end with words spoken by one of the actors; and in each case this is justified by the scheme of the trilogy to which the play belonged.

p.#text: The use of  is peculiar. I take the exact sense to be:  the final day as on a point towards which one is moving, , i.e. until one shall have had experience of it. Thus  is used in a sense closely akin to its common sense of  attentively considering a thing: and the whole phrase is virtually equivalent to,  the final day. For the added infin., cp.  Cp.   Hartung proposed to replace  by  where  would be intolerable; Stanley by , Seyffert by , and Nauck by . Kennedy, keeping  changes  into  But the infin.  as a  sententious imperative see on 462 is appropriate in this  The accus.  stands with the infin. when, as here, the infin. represents an imperat. of the  person; cp.  with Leaf's note: and Madvig  sect. 546. When the infin. = an imperat. of the  pers., the case is regularly the nom. , rarely the acc. . The view that  depends on  requires a shorter pause at  and thus weakens the effect of v. 1527. .  partly reproduces the language of this passage:  He has the thought also in , , , as Soph. in  and fr. 588. The maxim,  Call no man happy before death, first appears in Greek literature as a set  in : but Aristotle recognises the popular tradition which ascribed it to Solon. In  Solon says that a man may be called   life, but  only  a life exempt from reverse. Cp.   where Mayor refers to the proverbs  Croesus  and  Parmoemiogr. 11. 187, I. 315 n., and to notices of the saying in Cic.  2.87, 3.76, Diog. Laert. , Ovid , Seneca  11.12, Josephus  1.5.11=29.3, Arrian 7 sect. 16.7, Lucian  10: cp. Ecclus. 11. 28. Does Solon mean, Aristotle asks, 1 that a man  happy when he is dead? Or 2 that, after death, he  happy? If 1, Arist. declines to allow that the dead are positively happy; and popular opinion, he says, denies that they are always negatively so, i.e. free from unhapppiness. If 2, then is it not absurd that at the time when he happy we are not to call him so? The fallacy, he concludes, consists  in treating happiness as dependant on bright :
